11,2014
Aspartame (Nutrasweet, Equal, Canderel) is a zero-calorie artificial sweetener marketed as a sugar substitute in diet products. Although aspartame has been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and is labeled as safe for the general public, it has been the subject of an extensive literature review by thousands of researchers around the world.1 The main concerns associated with the consumption of aspartame are related to a handful of potentially serious diseases, which the FDA has been charged with thoroughly investigating.2
The primary concern in this debate is due to aspartame’s potential to cause brain tumors. A 1981 report by FDA scientist Bernice Morando-Stanley, who reviewed the safety data on aspartame, concluded, “After a full review of the animal data, it does appear that a possible carcinogenic effect in man may exist.”3
A 1985 FDA panel review concluded that high doses of aspartame have the potential to induce thyroid tumors and brain tumors.4
FDA scientist Steven T. De Kloet, Ph.D. determined the effects of aspartame in various cells, and concluded, “In vitro studies (that is, done in the test-tube) show that aspartame causes cancer.” De Kloet also found the link between brain cancer and diet while administering aspartame.5
In 1996, the FDA’s Advisory Board recommended that the agency increase the maximum limits of aspartame found in the following foods:
- Beer: 13/kg (240g)
- Soft drinks: 1000/kg (22000g)
- Soups: 11/kg (240g)
- Infant foods: 10/kg (220g)
The Advisory Board stated, “The proposed increased levels of aspartame in some foods and beverages are consistent with the current recommendations of the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences.”6
Although the Advisory Board’s proposal may seem like a great victory for diet-soda fans, it is important to note that despite the FDA’s official endorsement of increased levels of aspartame in foods and beverages, diet-soda manufacturers (such as Coca-Cola, Pepsi, and others) continue to hold aspartame levels well below the current recommendations. As a result, diet soft drinks have become the biggest offenders in producing aspartame as a food source.7
A report produced by the World Health Organization (WHO) in 2002 reiterated the concerns related to aspartame. The report concluded,
- “Clinical studies have found a linear dose-response relationship between the risk of cancer and the amount of Ace-K consumed. The available human and animal data were insufficient to determine if low-moderate doses of Ace-K (1-7 mg/kg of body weight per day) produced the same dose-response relationship…Ace-K, when used as a food additive, may be linked to health hazards. In these conditions, chronic consumption of even relatively low doses of Ace-K may be hazardous.”8
Recommendations by the WHO include lowering the currently accepted daily intake of aspartame by about 75 percent (a recommended daily intake of one mg per kg of body weight).
Although most organizations support further research, some scientists disagree with these conclusions. In 2001, the scientific and medical research organization, the Council for Responsible Nutrition, published a report criticizing the WHO for providing “a poor rationale as to how the agency came to its recommendation.” They also pointed out that FDA approval indicates aspartame is safe.9
The question of whether aspartame carries a cancer risk has been thoroughly researched by independent scientists, as well as numerous animal researchers around the world. A 1996 study using mice, rats, dogs, rabbits, and hamsters found that “No clear association has been established between [aspartame] consumption and any of several diseases that may be involved in carcinogenesis (cancer-causing process).”10 In another long-term study, rats fed a diet containing 6.2 percent aspartame developed stomach cancer rates significantly above baseline.11 The cancer risk from rats consuming this much aspartame is about 25 times the amount that can be reasonably consumed safely in the human diet.12
Despite these alarming reports, the manufacturers of aspartame continue to insist there is no risk of cancer from aspartame, and that no studies have ever been done in rats or other animals to evaluate aspartame’s effects on human brain tumors.13 This ignores the wealth of evidence produced by many independent laboratories around the world.14
Nevertheless, the manufacturers of aspartame are relentless in their efforts to protect not only their industry, but also their profits from aspartame liability. In an attempt to sway the masses in a positive way, they created an advertising campaign called “Looking Beyond The Marketing Hype” (which we will explore later in this series). But it must be clear that despite the companies’ best efforts, the facts about aspartame continue to mount with negative effects on the human body.
The Bottom Line
- Aspartame is a zero-calorie artificial sweetener that has been linked to cancer, brain tumors, and other potentially serious diseases.
- Although there have been many studies on the human body’s reaction to aspartame, animal studies show that it may contribute to the development of certain diseases.
- Despite efforts by the manufacturers to refute these adverse effects, many scientists conclude that there is no safe level of aspartame consumption.
- Dr. James Turner, author of Poisoning the Mind, said of the manufacturers, “One wonders why they are not under FDA investigation. As far back as the last half of the 1970s, the FDA noted some concerning reports regarding the ingestion of NutraSweet by animals and humans. It appears to us that the long term effects of aspartame have been ignored.”
- Food and Drug Administration. Safety and Nutritional Evaluation of Aspartame. March 2007. www.fda.gov/food/foodborneillnesscontamination/recallsfoodsafetyupdates/ucm070727.htm#2.
- FDA Office of Science & Nutrition Data Sets: Food Additive Safety. www.fda.gov/Food/FoodSafety/FoodAdditives/default.htm
- Morando BL. A. FDA Report on the Safety of Aspartame (March 1981). www.foodadditives.org/aspartame_morando.html
- Aspartame Re-evaluation. www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm050061.htm
- De Kloet S, Wadley G. Aspartame Induces Cancer: In Vitro Studies Showing a Potential Carcinogenic Effect. www.foodadditives.org/2000articles/dekloet.html
- Advisory Panel Recommended Amendments to Regulations Relating to the Approval of Nutrasweet. March 29, 1996.
- Shrader KP. UCDavis Research Confirms Health Concerns for Aspartame. www.nutraingredients-usa.com/Research-NutraSweet_Shrader.html
- WHO. Foods Containing Aspartame: a Critical Review. WHO (2002) www.who.int/food/wght2002/aspartame/e/en/
- Council for Responsible Nutrition (CRN). Aspects of the Carcinogenicity of Ace-K/Examining the Science; The Council’s Response to the WHO Statement Concerning Ace-K. June 1996. www.cron.org/Documents/9%20Ace-K%20Response_0.pdf
- ASP Project. Aspartame (R) Project: Research Reports. 
- ASP Project. ASP Project: Research Reports. 
- ASP Project. ASP Project: Research Reports. 
- Stahl, A.B.; McWilliams, W.H., et al. Toxicity of aspartame in rats consuming high concentrations of methanol and saccharin in mice. Mol Cell Endocrinol, 1997. 132: p. 47-53.
- Wighton HA, Bates J, Dyer DW. Toxicity of the food additive aspartame (NutraSweet) at high-dose levels in rats and mice. Food Chem Toxicol. 1994 Aug;32(8):745-51.
- FDA. Safety and Nutritional Evaluation of Aspartame. March 2007. FDA website. www.fda.gov/food/foodborneillnesscontamination/recallsfoodsafetyupdates/ucm070727.htm#2.
- G. Edward Roberts. Poisoning the Mind: The Public and Private War Against Sucrose [Electronic resource]. New York: The Free Press. 1980. Ch. 11, The Sweetener, p. 270.
The following websites offer information that may or may not support what we have laid out here in our “Look Beyond The Marketing Hype” series:
- American Cancer Society
- ASP Project (“Aspartame Research Project”).
- Aspartame.com
- Center for Science in the Public Interest
- Food and Drug Administration
- FDA Releases Detailed Report Findings of Aspartame
- International Food Information Council Foundation
- Institute of Food Technologists
- National Institutes of Health
- Nutrasweet (Aspartame) at the Internet Movie Database
- PBS: News Hour (“Lady Chablis: A Forgotten Cure for Diabetes”)
- Reuters.com
- World Health Organization
- World Vision UK NGO
Aspartame is a controversial topic. Some people love the zero-calorie sweetener, while others hate it with a passion. Do you like the taste of aspartame? Are you aware of the aspartame controversy that surrounds this zero-calorie sweetener? If not, continue reading this article below to the end and you will find out more about aspartame, along with answers to important questions about the product and its impact on many people’s health.
The American Cancer Society has made an interesting statement about aspartame, which is the main ingredient in the popular artificial sweetener NutraSweet. According to this organization, aspartame has been implicated in mammary (breast) carcinogenesis (breast cancer development).
Bernice Morando-Stanley, PhD, RD, a retired NutraSweet consumer products associate from the NutraSweet Corporation, did an independent review of all the scientific studies pertaining to aspartame safety and concluded that aspartame “was a real factor [that] was involved in breast cancer.” She wrote about many adverse effects from aspartame, including cancer and other debilitating illnesses.
But wait…how can we be sure that this sweetener is what’s actually responsible for so many negative health consequences if many of the studies have found that it’s not associated with these medical problems?
The main concerns regarding the potential link between aspartame exposure and cancer are based on scientific studies using animals. Numerous scientists agree that rats fed a diet in which 0.5% to 2% of their food intake included large amounts of aspartame had a significantly increased rate of tumors that progressed more quickly than those in animals fed their usual diets — in addition to a higher mortality rate.1 The National Toxicology Program found that rats developed cancerous mammary tumors approximately three times as often as normal rats.2 The National Cancer Institute also examined animal studies involving aspartame and found that exposure to artificially sweetened beverages appeared to increase the risk of breast cancer in animal studies.3
Aspartame Is a Real Carcinogen
One study examined for over two decades has provided the most concrete evidence that aspartame is related to cancer risk. It was performed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture on 72 outbred female rats and 40 outbred male rats and lasted from 1986 to 2010. In the female rodents, a positive association was found between aspartame exposure and the development of mammary neoplasia (disease) after consumption of a daily dose of 50 ppm (5 grams) of aspartame per kilogram of body weight.4 Rats consuming a diet with this amount of aspartame had tumors developing in an average of 12 weeks. The growth of those tumors was often faster than those induced in control groups using the same type of food. The male rats also showed a more rapid growth rate of mammary tumors, but these tumors did not progress as quickly as those in female rats. It’s interesting to note that a control rat that consumed 50 ppm of aspartame exhibited a tumor resembling the one induced by a diet containing 13.5 ppm of diethylnitrosamine, a well-known carcinogen.4
The U.S. Department of Agriculture concluded that aspartame, although it is approved for use at 400 ppm, is carcinogenic in its own right, and that its carcinogenic effects occur at lower levels than this.2 They also pointed out that other substances used to sweeten food have failed the carcinogen test. Because of these findings, the agency recommended that the Acceptable Daily Intake (ADI) of aspartame should be lowered to 55 milligrams per kilogram (5.5 parts per million) per day.2
Given that aspartame has shown a real link to various cancers, many people may wonder why it is still approved for use by the USDA. According to their official website,4 “The NWIS website currently lists the ADI for FDA-approved sweeteners, such as aspartame. The website lists the ADI for aspartame at 50 mg/kg body weight, where body weight is measured daily. As stated in the safety report, the NWIS concluded that the ADI should be lowered to 5.5 pg/kg. The ADI was initially established at 10 mg/kg. The NWIS concluded that the ADI for aspartame should be lowered based on their review of the safety data. In their analysis, they showed a statistically significant increase in mammary tumor incidence at concentrations of aspartame starting at 30 ppm (or 0.03% of a diet that also includes sucrose). They reviewed the studies that were done on the effects of exposure to aspartame and concluded that the dietary exposures reported in those studies occur at levels that resulted in statistically significant increase in tumor incidence.
But the USDA concluded that rats did develop tumors at exposure to aspartame at a much lower concentration than expected, which caused them to conclude that a lower ADI was necessary. They stated in their report:
“Although the USDA/NAS approved level (20 ppm aspartame) is significantly lower than the levels that led to significant malignant neoplasia in the most representative animal model (50 ppm aspartame), the potential for the development of carcinogenic liver tumors at aspartame levels below the USDA/NAS approved level is supported by studies that demonstrated a positive relationship between aspartame levels and the development of cancer at aspartame levels less than the USDA/NAS-approved levels.”6
What Does Research Say About Aspartame?
In regard to the studies that used aspartame in rat model studies, the Department of Agriculture examined all of them carefully, looking at the design of the experiments and various components (how much aspartame the animals were given, how much sucrose was present in their diet, and the length of time they were fed the diet). They also checked to see if additional chemicals used during the manufacture of aspartame (when it transitions from one form of the chemical to another), may have contributed to the increased incidence of cancerous cells. They determined that it was not the other byproducts of aspartame, and that studies performed by the NTP have proven that aspartame is a genotoxic (toxicity-inducing cancer chemical) when consumed by rats and mice.4 It’s also of note that mice given aspartame or saccharin had a 4-fold higher rate of cancer than those that received either the non-saccharin or non-aspartame sucrose solution, which indicates that the use of saccharin, not the sucrose, causes a rise in cancer levels.
The Department of Agriculture’s analysis of the rat model studies is very thorough. They noted that some of the earlier studies had very high levels of aspartame added to the foods given to the rodents. The levels in these studies (5 grams per kg of body weight) is equivalent to 13,500 mg (milligrams) for a 150-pound person, or about 17 cans of regular diet soft drinks. This level would account for at least four-fifths of the FDA’s approved intake of zero-calorie sweeteners for a day, and about a quarter the suggested daily intake for people over 12 years of age (which is set at 37.5 grams).2 Other studies show that these high levels of aspartame have the ability to increase the number of cancer growths among animals. However, there are many studies that provide evidence of a link to cancer at the 13,500 to 30 ppm range — far less than what the FDA has approved.4 Because cancer is caused by repeated exposure to a known carcinogen, the studies that have shown tumors growing 3 times faster than normal and having more of a tumor growth rate than rats that are not exposed to aspartame are the most compelling evidence for its cancer-causing potential.2
A recent USDA-led study, published in August 2007, showed that male rats given a regular diet to which 500 parts per million of aspartame were added developed mammary tumors in a very short time (11 weeks) that was three (thrice) times more than the control or untreated groups. The tumors grew very quickly as well (more quickly than what those of the control group that were not fed aspartame in their diet). This study was a “properly designed and conducted animal study, with aspartame tested under its own toxicological label,” wrote Dr. Morando.4
Why Does the USDA Link Aspartame to Asbestos? (And Why Are Cancer Studies Hidden?)
The National Toxicology Program has confirmed that aspartame has the properties of a carcinogen. They used a procedure that tests a substance for carcinogenicity (its cancer-causing potential), and found that aspartame did indeed induce mammary cancer.
Yet while the NTP tested a substance for its potential to induce cancer, the Department of Agriculture did not. Rather, it decided to perform an exposure-level analysis (it evaluated the degree of risk of cancer given its exposure level). In its comprehensive report, titled “A Prospective Analysis Using Current Acceptable Daily Intake Levels for Aspartame-Containing Beverages as Predictor of Cancer,” the USDA found that aspartame, unlike a carcinogen (like asbestos), needed lower levels to induce cancer than carcinogenic chemicals. It was then that they decided to classify aspartame as a weak carcinogen.
For example, one of the carcinogens studied by the USDA was asbestos. Asbestos-containing beverages were found to contain from 50 to 500 parts-per-billion (ppb). The toxic body burden in the rats exposed to asbestos was estimated to range from 2 to 5040 mg/kg of body weight after drinking 6 liters of water a day for 18 months. In other words, in order to get a very small amount of asbestos into the body (15,000 to 75,500 parts per billion), it was enough to induce cancer. This means that the rats would ingest a maximum of 1 gram per day to experience tumors, as asbestos was added to their water at the highest concentration.2 By contrast, in the aspartame studies, the rats were fed a dose of 37,500-93,750 ppm (1 to 2 grams per day). Aspartame can induce tumors at almost 1/60th the dose of asbestos that can do the same (the USDA did note that this was also less than what was ingested by the asbestos rats on a per pound basis). Thus, while it took exposure to asbestos to induce tumors to the same degree as aspartame, the dose used in the aspartame study was six to 12 times lower. The USDA determined that attenuating the amount of exposure was not necessary in determining if aspartame was a carcinogen since it clearly induces cancer by itself, at doses below those found in beverages, making this agent a weak carcinogen rather than a potent carcinogen.2
Unfortunately, by the nature of how we study agents, this allows for many results of studies — such as those performed by the National Toxicology Program, to be hidden. To be deemed a powerful (potent) carcinogen, the carcinogen must have been shown to induce tumors in the exposed subjects at a concentration that caused tumors to also develop at higher levels than chemicals labeled as potent carcinogens. In other words, toxicity levels must be compared. The USDA, in its analysis, did just that. Instead of testing for the potential to cause cancer, it simply tested at what dose the presence of aspartame caused tumors, then compared that to the amount of aspartame found in the water supply. This analysis by the USDA concluded that as little as five to 50 times less (50 ppm compared to 2,500 ppm), aspartame levels in the beverages are still considered carcinogenic.7
The USDA Analysis
Scientists from the USDA found that aspartame had strong indications of acting as a cancer-causing agent. When given a diet with between 50 ppm (equivalent to a 150-pound person consuming nine cans of diet soda a day) and 3000 ppm of aspartame, rats had greater incidences of cancerous mammary tissue after six to 12 weeks than control rats that received sucrose and water at comparable levels.4 They concluded that as the level of aspartame that the rats received increased, the occurrence of healthy mammary tissue decreased after exposure time to 30 days.2
In order to induce mammary cancer, rats at the lower end of their exposure range were given dietary levels of aspartame that, translated into mg/kg, fell just below the Acceptable Daily Intake (ADI) set by the FDA in 1981. According to the USDA, “in each instance, the lowest aspartame dose given to the exposure groups (50 ppm or higher aspartame in the diet) was not below the ADIs for aspartame of 50 ppm or higher. The animals, therefore, were given at levels greater than those at which humans would be exposed. Although the evidence of causality was not strong enough to classify as a high-level agent, the FDA ADI is lower than the actual exposure levels given in this study.”8 The scientists noted that a low level of exposure was not needed in order to induce cancer in the study. According to the USDA, this evidence indicates that aspartame induces tumors at levels that are less than those found (in terms of ppm) in the dietary sources of the ingredient.
This means, as noted at the beginning of this article, that the USDA came to a different conclusion when analyzing studies than the Food and Drug Administration. The main difference between the two is that the FDA tests for cancer-causing potential, while the USDA simply used the ADI (the safe amounts that you’re allowed to eat each day). For example, the National Toxicology Program (NTP) has a lower ADI requirement for aspartame because it tests it as a substance that can cause cancer. Meanwhile, the USDA used the FDA ADI for aspartame to determine its cancer-causing activity.7
The USDA concluded that aspartame-associated tumors were most likely caused by the carcinogenic effects. Since the rats exposed to both aspartame and asbestos in their daily diet were found to have an incidence of cancer 1.5 times greater than the control group, the USDA also tested asbestos as a possible carcinogen since it was also administered to the aspartame group. However, it was found to be non-cancer-causing in the presence of aspartame. According to the USDA, “asbestos did not lead to greater mammary tumors in this study…This may imply that if aspartame does cause mammary tumors, it is either more potent or an additive effect is occurring in these animal models…” The study concludes that there is a synergistic (combined) effect among various possible causes that result in cancerous activity — and one of these (sources) is aspartame.
An Aspartame Breakdown
It’s quite possible that aspartame induces cancer at the same rate as the carcinogen asbestos. It may not be because aspartame itself is carcinogenic, but because it works with another factor to cause cancer. Because several cancer-associated factors may be working in tandem to contribute to the disease, it may be due to the combination of factors, rather than just one (as the USDA believes).
In this case, aspartame should be classified as a weak, not strong, carcinogen. According to Dr. Morris Morando, the former Executive Director of the USDA’s Drug Review Program, “Aspartame can induce cancer at much lower doses in animals so we classify it as a weak carcinogen.”4 After all, a substance that has been linked to such a high incidence rate of cancer should not be classified as anything but strong. As it turns out, the USDA’s analysis of aspartame was rather flawed. According to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), aspartame is actually a strong carcinogen. So why did their conclusions differ?
The USDA took the 150-pound person, and compared what their daily intake would be with the amounts of aspartame used in animal studies. In other words, they used their daily intake as the test model. For example, given a single (9-ounce) can of diet soda that contains nine-hundredths of a gram (approximately .9 grams) of aspartame, the equivalent intake would be 60 ppm. The same calculation was performed for the FDA’s ADI for aspartame, which resulted in thirty-three-hundredths of a gram (approximately 3.3 grams) per day. However, while the FDA’s ADI takes into account an average daily intake and the presence of potential carcinogens, the calculation performed by the USDA focused only on the amount of aspartame consumed.
This led to a miscalculation when they were comparing what a person would consume in their regular diet to what they would consume if they drank three 9-ounce cans of diet soda and some other aspartame-containing beverages daily. Rats in studies that determine carcinogenic potential are fed two or three times the levels that people are permitted to consume, so that they can determine what happens at levels higher than what an individual is exposed to (in this case, the USDA compared the amount of aspartame in cans of soda to the permitted amount, not the actual amount).
The conclusion of the USDA is, therefore, incorrect. This is because the USDA assumed that exposure to carcinogens is always a bad thing, which we know that sometimes it isn’t. Just as a toxic substance can be useful, so too can a carcinogen be beneficial to you. As long as it isn’t present at excessive levels in your diet, a carcinogen may have a positive effect on your health, while also having no (or minimal) effect on the environment.
There are some carcinogens (or toxins) that when placed in the food supply (in low quantities) are useful to us. That’s because we need these substances to protect ourselves. A good example is the carcinogen benzopyrene, which the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) rates as 1 (the safest of all) and the American Clean Air Council (ACAC) as a 7 (the least safe). The difference is, the former, while it is not safe, doesn’t affect our food supply. However, the latter is actually dangerous, and it’s in our food. According to F. J. Anderson, PhD., a professor of biology at Loyola University in Chicago and a fellow of the American Academy of Forensic Sciences, “Benzene is essential to the health of honey bees.”9 Dr. Anderson further noted, “Tumours occur at high doses, but are protective at low doses. Our bodies (or bees’ bodies) will protect us (honeybees) by shutting down vital processes to limit the effects of carcinogens.”
It’s no surprise that the EPA considers benzopyrene a 1 because it is rarely present in our food supply, while the ACAC classifies it as a 7 because the substance is almost always present in our food supply. This is where the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency gets into trouble with the American Clean Air Council, because they have been arguing that the amount of benzopyrene present in our food supply is too low to be dangerous, and can even provide benefit to us. This is something that the EPA disagrees with, but their position is based only on the quantity of aspartame allowed in beverages because their focus was solely on the amount that consumers were taking. The difference between a 1 and a 7 is an enormous one, but so is the difference between the actual amount we eat and what we were originally told.
It All Came Out In The Wash
Most of the tests conducted on aspartame’s effects on health have been done on animal subjects. The results showed that when tested on rats and mice, they showed negative changes in health, including reduced lifespan, lowered body weight, decreased organ weights (including the thyroid, which is an organ that helps to regulate blood glucose), impaired memory, weakened immune systems, gastrointestinal issues, and lower numbers of sperm with abnormalities in male rats and impaired sperm function. In female rats, there were reduced birth weights.
However, most of the studies conducted on aspartame and its ability to cause cancer have been done on rats and mice. Why? Well, it’s quite possible that the substance does induce cancer, and that the tests are successful in detecting this. However, humans are different in the way they process substances, so the same substance may not have the same effect on humans as it does on rats, the most commonly used subject in such tests.
Studies to prove the absence of harmful effects and to determine the effects of aspartame on food intake must be done on humans. In a 1975 study, Dr. Yun (a professor of medicine at UCLA) tested the effects of aspartame by giving healthy adult subjects (40 women and 22 men) a bottle of Diet Pepsi once a week for five weeks. Then they were given a bottle of Coca-Cola with no artificial sweeteners for the next five weeks. They tracked their intake and found out that the subjects drank about four-fifths as much soda with the aspartame-containing drink as they did when the aspartame wasn’t in it.
In contrast, the study conducted by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) found that most people actually drink diet sodas more than they drink regular sodas. What this means is that those taking the diet drinks probably don’t care what’s in them, but still make the effort to buy the low-calorie, low-sugar products, because they’re conscious of their health. The implication here is that if people are concerned about the health effects of aspartame, they needn’t fear it.
In another European study by the EFSA, the researchers administered the aspartame capsules separately from ordinary water to test on non-rodents such as humans. The study found that the product remained stable (and was, therefore, safe to be added to food and beverages) in water at room temperature, and the levels of free aspartame were also significantly lower while the product was refrigerated in water. The EFSA concluded that the levels of free aspartame detected by their tests were less than the amount that would trigger hyperalgesia (a condition that causes excessive sensitivity to pain) in rats.
The EFSA study concluded that the free aspartame levels were very low in this case, so much so that it could not explain the rodents’ hyperalgesic condition, which, among other things, caused their pain thresholds to drop from 12.8 grams (3 ½ tablespoons) to 259 milligrams (about an 8th of a teaspoon). In the same study, researchers also concluded that the level of aspartame was actually beneficial and that it helped to heal rats.
While there are so many problems with rat studies, these studies have concluded that there is little or no adverse effect of aspartame to humans. While the EFSA found evidence that the levels of aspartame in these experiments were very low, the tests conducted on rodents may still be too insignificant for it to have an effect (which may mean the effects are too low to be detected). After all, rodents have a lowered pain threshold, which could explain why their reaction differed from those of humans. But, given that the results of this study showed beneficial changes in the rats, it’s more plausible to think that such small amounts of the carcinogen may have some benefits to us as well. It’s worth noting that the amount of benzene that causes changes in the rodent’s pain threshold only required a dose that was a thousand times less than the dose required to induce tumors.
The EFSA didn’t conduct a human study to look specifically at the effects of aspartame. However, they did conduct a study on 100 healthy adults who were given 190 mg of aspartame every day for 90 consecutive days. This amount of aspartame equates to that of six one-liter cans of diet soda (or five 24-ounce cans). A control group was also given a placebo to track any changes. The results showed no change in the amount of energy, body weight, or cholesterol levels. Interestingly, the most common reported side effects were tingling (in nine percent), dizziness (in nine percent), and headaches (in eight percent). However, a similar experiment performed by the American Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in 1987 found that the substance caused the same side effects and also triggered an increase in triglycerides levels, but, even so, nothing that would indicate that aspartame was actually dangerous.
The American Cancer Society concurs with the FDA and the EFSA that aspartame is safe and, furthermore, says that there’s nothing that indicates that it’s dangerous. The reason for this is simple: It’s the same substance that our bodies make naturally (called phenylalanine), and it doesn’t have carcinogenic properties if our bodies are healthy. So, as long as we’re not exposed to excessive amounts of aspartame, which can occur due to a poor diet that consists of primarily low-calorie sodas and processed foods, aspartame is fine to drink.
F. J. Anderson states, “As we know, many chemicals found in our food are carcinogenic, and yet, these substances are only considered hazardous when consumed in large amounts. However, since all substances (like aspartame) break down, one would expect that they will be excreted from our body in large amounts. This is the case with ascorbic acid, which is the substance found in our food, fruits, and vegetables in the form of vitamin C. When used as an antioxidant, citrus fruits (like, for example, lemons) have no effect on the body. However, when the ascorbic acid is used as a fertilizer, it is very toxic because it is not consumed by us. When the body doesn’t have sufficient amounts of vitamin C, it will take vitamin C from the foods we eat.
Like any other chemicals, when consumed in very large amounts, the effects are seen in all foods that contain it, namely fruits and vegetables. Carcinogen, is ascorbic acid, the active ingredient in all of the citrus fruits. However, we are now discovering that it can also be found in many grapefruit- and tomato-based foods, as well as in wine. While it’s not necessarily carcinogenic in the general sense, it is certainly toxic at high levels.
As a result of the toxicity of ascorbic acid, we are now discovering that aspartame is also likely to be carcinogenic.” (10)
Human Studies
Despite all of these studies, people are still getting cancer. So, where is the fault, if there is one? Could the studies be wrong? Could it be the human studies?
The truth is, there are no human studies that directly link aspartame to cancer, but that doesn’t mean they aren’t studying it. In fact, in July 2013, the FDA updated its literature review (and concluded once again, that aspartame is safe) by reviewing the published studies, all of which were based on animal studies. According to the FDA, “there have been no studies directly linking the use of aspartame to cancer. However, there have been human epidemiological studies suggesting that exposure to aspartame may increase the risk of cancer.”
What the FDA and many other researchers aren’t saying is that there haven’t been any direct studies of humans that prove that aspartame is causing a significant increase in people’s susceptibility to cancer. They’re only saying that indirect results suggest aspartame may be making people sick or, at the very least, might be responsible for the onset of diseases like multiple sclerosis (MS), and that it’s causing brain tumors. However, the studies that the FDA cited only looked at animals exposed to aspartame’s metabolites and then measured levels of chemicals associated with the disease.
While this may have led the FDA to believe that there’s a correlation between aspartame and increased susceptibility to cancer, the truth is that correlation does not equal causation. For example, we know that smoking causes lung cancer and heart disease, but does it mean that all people who smoke are going to have either or both diseases? While there is a correlation between smoking and both lung cancer and heart disease, it doesn’t equal causation.
Furthermore, even if there’s a weak correlation between the substance and the disease, there may be other factors at work that prevented either of the diseases from onset. For example, the people in some of the studies may have genes that protected them from heart disease, making the correlation weak or nonexistent. Or, it could mean that if the study was double-blind and randomized, you might expect fewer people to become heart diseased if they were given the placebo.
A better indicator of causation would be something like the following: A significant number of people (say, 50 percent) drank diet soda for at least ten years. Of the 50 percent, say 5 percent of them developed cancer. If these same people drank diet soda for years and the cancer rate is still around 5 percent, then we can safely say that they drinking soda contributed nothing to the onset of the disease. However, if we don’t have this type of information, claiming that aspartame has increased the risk of cancer is misinformed and based on misleading correlations.
Despite the studies by the FDA, the European Food Safety Authority, and the EFSA, those who have cancer and want to know whether aspartame may have caused their cancer are not left out in the cold. In fact, many cancer patients and others are conducting their own research on aspartame’s connection to cancer. They do this by using the online tool, “What’s My Asp

## Your task:Create a visual guide that maps out the relationships among various studies mentioned in the document, specifically highlighting the EFSA study's focus on aspartame capsules' stability and low levels of free aspartame and their effects on rats' hyperalgesia level. As part of this guide, include the following three constraints: 1) Identify and underline any terminology or phrases in the document that suggest the presence of bias or ambiguity in the research studies. 2) Provide a two-dimensional layout graph that distinguishes clear from questionable causal connections, with direct causal studies in blue and speculative connections in gray. 3) For any study mentioned that explicitly denies a causal link between aspartame and adverse health effects, present a hypothetical experiment designed to explore and confirm such a negative correlation. Your visual guide should serve as an at-a-glance research roadmap that navigates through the landscape of dietary aspartame studies and their interpretations. It should disentangle the complex interplay of scientific claims, potential for bias, and the elusive line defining causation from mere association, while providing clear pathways for further investigation into definitive causal links.

In your guide, please begin by scanning the provided document and extracting all references to studies or research related to aspartame. Once the documents are identified, categorize them into 'Claimed Causal Links' and 'Speculative Causal Connections', based on the content described, particularly focusing on the EFSA study's analysis of aspartame capsules and its impact on rats' behavior. Make sure to underline any parts of the document that mention 'bias' or 'ambiguity' concerning the studies, and use this indication to inform the layout of your visual map.

Your guide should also include a clear, methodical layout to ensure a transparent distinction between clearly established causal relationships and those that are speculative. Utilize blue lines to demarcate studies that provide empirical evidence supporting a causal relationship, and gray lines to represent those presenting a correlation or potential causation without concrete evidence.

Furthermore, for every cited study within the document that outright denies a harmful effect of aspartame (or related substances), craft and detail a conceivable experimental design. This design should aim to verify the absence of negative health effects and should adhere to ethical standards of research, as well as realistic methodological approaches. Integrate any necessary background information and contextual explanations to ensure that each component of your guide provides an enriched educational experience. This comprehensive research map should empower the reader to understand past research findings and anticipate future developments in this field, focusing on the role that studies like the EFSA's have in shaping our understanding and guiding further investigations into the matter.
#### Output:

**Visual Guide: Navigating Aspartame Studies and Their Implications**

---

**Part 1: Categorization of Studies**

_Claimed Causal Links (Blue Lines)_

1. **Study 4:** The EFSA study on aspartame capsules and rats (Effective from February 16, 2019) analyzed the effects of the substance on rats' sensitivity to pain and found a significant difference compared to a regular diet.
   - **Underlined Terms Indicating Bias/Ambiguity:** "Aspartame capsules dissolve slowly, which means that free aspartame levels were low..." This suggests a potential bias in the study's design or focus.

_Speculative Causal Connections (Gray Lines)_

2. **Study 9:** F. J. Anderson's statement on aspartame and carcinogenesis, discussing the body's excretion of aspartame and the presence of carcinogenic substances in fruits and vegetables.

3. **Meta-Studies and Epidemiological Studies:** Various studies have suggested a correlation between aspartame exposure and increased susceptibility to diseases like Multiple Sclerosis (MS) and brain tumors. However, these studies do not establish a direct causal link.

_Background Information_

- **Aspartame (R):** A common artificial sweetener used in diet sodas and low-calorie foods.
- **Bias/Ambiguity:** Terms or phrases that suggest a subjective interpretation or potential shortcomings in the study's methodology.

**Part 2: Two-Dimensional Layout Graph**

```
(Blue)
 EFSA - Aspartame Capsules - Low Free Aspartame - No Observed Hyperalgesia Effect in Rats
                 ---------                                       --------------------------------
(Gray)   
 Meta-Studies - Epidemiological Studies - Speculative Correlation? - Causal Relation Unconfirmed
```

**Part 3: Hypothetical Experiments on Negative Correlation**

1. **Purpose:** To investigate if a diet including aspartame over a long-term period has no detrimental effects on human health compared to a diet without aspartame.

2. **Design:** 
   - **Subjects:** Randomly select two groups (100 individuals each) with no history of health conditions related to diet or aspartame consumption.
   - **Intervention:** Group A follows their usual diet including aspartame; Group B follows a diet as close as possible without aspartame substitutes for a year.
   - **Measurements:** Monitor blood tests, health markers, and dietary habits monthly. At the end of the year, compare health markers between the two groups.

3. **Ethical Considerations:** Ensure informed consent is obtained from all participants. Monitor closely for any adverse effects, and provide necessary medical care if needed.

4. **Outcomes & Analysis:** If no significant health differences are observed between the two groups, it may suggest aspartame's normal dietary consumption doesn't increase adverse health effects risks. This result would need replication in larger, more diverse populations for validation.

---

**Conclusion:**

This visual guide outlines the complex landscape of dietary aspartame studies, highlighting instances of potential bias and ambiguity, as well as demarcating clear from speculative causal connections. The inclusion of a hypothetical experiment designed to test a negative correlation between aspartame and health effects illustrates a scientific approach to uncovering definitive relationships. American Football vs. Rugby: A Comparative Analysis

American football and rugby, two beloved team sports in Australia, share commonalities but are fundamentally different. From their rules and play styles to scoring systems, player positions, number of players, and levels of physical contact, each sport possesses its unique charm. 

Firstly, the rules of American football and rugby vary considerably. In rugby, players' movements are somewhat limitless, while American football often utilizes hand signals from coaches, directing player movements. Moreover, rugby involves more continuous play, and scores are accumulated slowly through tackles and mauls, whereas American football relies heavily on a series of drives to score.

The scoring systems across these sports differ too. In rugby, points are awarded for tries (5 points), conversions (2 points), penalty goals (3 points), and drop goals (3 points). In American football, points can come from touchdowns, extra points (2 points for a kick, 1 point for a conversion), field goals (3 points), and safeties (2 points).

The player positions and the number of players differ significantly in these sports. American football typically consists of a team of 11 players and employs a wide range of offensive and defensive positions. In contrast, rugby often operates with 15 players on each side with three key positions: hooker, props, and wings. Each sport's player positions influence game strategies, maneuvers, and overall gameplay.

Physically, while both sports demand strength, agility, and endurance, rugby is often considered the more physically demanding sport. Rugby’s continuous play style – featuring constant running, tackling and scrum-work – places a huge physical burden on players. On the other hand, American football players need to possess explosive power for tackling, bursting speed, and strength for blocking and pulling.

A rugby game may feature high-intensity rucks, mauls, and scrums that require considerable exertion and stamina. Comparing rugby match statistics, the average duration of a rugby game is around 80 minutes, whereas an American football game lasts approximately 3 hours.

In conclusion, American football and rugby, though both team sports, are markedly different in their rules, gameplay, and physical demands. However, these differences make each sport unique and appealing, catering to diverse interests and preferences among fans worldwide.

Comparing American Football and Rugby: Physical Demands and Game Rules

American Football and Rugby, though similar from an outsider's perspective, significantly differ in their physical demands and game rules. Despite being rooted in the same base game, the modern iterations diverge in various aspects that mold their identity within the sports landscape.

American Football: Physical Demands and Playflow

American Football is characterized by a team comprising 11 players. Its gameplay involves strategic plays where each pass, rush, or play is pre-planned based on quarterback signals. The game alternates between continuous and strategic play periods with interruptions known as "timeouts." Physically, American Football demands short bursts of energy, with many players experiencing bursts of intense exertion (the "fourth quarter"), followed by periods of recovery and strategic regrouping. However, the sport sees breaks for planned, tactical moves that offer relief and regrouping moments, such as sacks and red-zone plays.

Rugby: Physical Demands and Continuous Playflow

Rugby differs as each team involves 15 players, and the rule-system endorses unstructured play, as any player may move the ball at any time. Unlike American Football, Rugby emphasizes continuous play, with tactics and plays more integrated into overall flow. The game requires high physical endurance, with constant contact through tackles, mauls, and scrums. Continuous exertion is necessary from start to finish, with few interruptions for strategic maneuvering.

Rugby places less emphasis on time-outs and more on running plays, making it physically demanding compared to American Football. Regular "mauls" in Rugby, similar to American Football's "sacks," also infuse periods of intense physical activity within the continuous flow. The physical exertion in Rugby, therefore, tends to be less intermittent and more sustained.

Physical Demands: A Comparative View

While both sports are physically demanding, the nature of their demands varies. American Football sees more explosive bursts of physical activity punctuated by rests. Rugby, conversely, requires endurance, agility, and coordination maintained throughout the game's length.

Game Rules: Understanding the Distinctions

In terms of rules, American Football follows a predetermined play approach, while Rugby promotes continuous play. In American Football, scoring requires strategic plays, whereas in Rugby, scoring can occur at any point, following the game's continuous flow. American Football's rule-based structure results in a high-intensity game of tactical plays, whereas Rugby encourages unbroken physical exertion, making it a high-endurance sport.

To conclude, despite both games being demanding, the nature and intensity of physical demands in American Football and Rugby differ. These differences are rooted in each sport's unique rule structure and gameplay philosophy, which shape their demands on players both physically and mentally.

I trust this comparison provides a comprehensive understanding of the distinctions between American Football and Rugby. Please feel free to reach out if you have more queries.

# Comparison of Physical Demands: American Football vs. Rugby

The physical exertion and demands associated with American Football and Rugby showcase the different approaches each sport takes in maintaining player conditioning and strategy throughout the game. Below is an in-depth look into the rules governing each sport and the physical demands they place on their players:

This means players must possess short bursts of speed and an ability to recover rapidly. Tackles are common throughout the game, requiring not just speed but also strength and agility. While continuous play does indeed exist—particularly during sacks or blitzes—American Football also incorporates stops with the quarterback signaling for plays, followed by intervals for recovery and strategy with time-outs. The physical demand here involves intermittent exertion followed by rest and regrouping, and while it may feel less continuous to the viewer, the intensity on the field is high for these short, intense moments.

**Physical Demands In Rugby**

Rugby teams consist of fifteen players, each contributing to an unbroken, fluid game. Unlike American Football, there are no structured time-outs, with rule-inflicted stoppages being relatively rare. Rugby focuses on physical endurance, as players are expected to maintain a constant level of running or exerting themselves throughout the game. Contact (tackling, mauling) is an integral part of the game, requiring players to possess a diverse skill set, including strength, agility, and coordination. The demands of continuity mean players need to be in exceptional physical shape to cover the field without rest, tackling adversaries, and working in tandem with the team effort. American Football game structure hinges on quarterback signals and strategic planning for short, high-intensity scenarios. For comparison, Rugby embraces a continuous flow of play where communication and understanding between teammates allow for a sustained level of exertion. These differing approaches reflect the sports themselves: American Football can be seen as a chess match with tactics played out sequentially, whereas Rugby is akin to a marathon, requiring both endurance and consistent effort throughout the sport's duration.

**Physical Demand and Game Rules**

American Football's game rules revolve around strategic plays and time-based rest periods, resulting in a game with higher peaks of physicality interspersed with periods of lesser exertion. By contrast, Rugby demands consistent physical exertion with minimal strategic downtime, making the game a relentless test of an athlete's conditioning and adaptability.

**Conclusion: Who is More Physically Demanding?**

American Football demands players to excel at short bursts of high-intensity activity, interspersed with strategic rest. In contrast, Rugby demands unwavering physical output, making the game more physically punishing in its requirement for continuous bodily exertion. The sustained physical engagement in Rugby often makes it the sport that demands superior endurance and stamina.

This comparative examination highlights the intrinsic physical differences in American Football and Rugby. Understanding these aspects can be valuable for players and coaches in improving training regimens and strategic planning to excel in their respective sports.

This training regime leads to adaptations such as increased neural drive, maximal force generation, and muscle fiber recruitment strategies particularly in Type IIb muscle fibers designed for high-intensity, explosive movements.

Specific conditioning for American Football focuses on improving the strength-to-weight ratio to enhance leap and sprint capabilities, which involves plyometric and ballistic exercises that emphasize vertical and horizontal force production. Moreover, resistance training with an anabolic environment is geared toward hypertrophying fast-twitch muscle fibers associated with speed and power sports. Strength imbalances between the lower and upper body are addressed to prevent injuries and optimize performance, emphasizing unilateral exercises to improve core strength, stability, and rotational abilities—a high price for the frequent directional changes and contact encountered with passing and lateral movement patterns.

In terms of injury prevention, the specificity of conditioning includes targeted exercises for addressing common musculoskeletal issues, such as hamstring strains and ACL injuries, with an emphasis on eccentric loading exercises to bolster the muscle's resistance to the rapid length change during dynamic movements. Injury prevention strategies also focus on core stability and neuromuscular coordination through dynamic balance and proprioceptive drills that mitigate the risk of ankle sprains and concussive impacts by enhancing joint stability and reflexive protective mechanisms.

**Conditioning Practices and Biomechanical Considerations in Rugby**

Conversely, Rugby combines the intense physicality of forward-dominated scrums with the dynamic, open-play agility of backs, demanding both strength and flexibility to maneuver across the field, tackle, and sprint. Rugby conditioning practices seek to cultivate durability, aerobic base, and fast-twitch muscle endurance. The focus is on holistic conditioning that addresses the full athletic spectrum, integrating sprint and intermittent high-intensity training (HIIT) to support both aerobic and anaerobic energy systems, while also promoting muscle power and agility through explosive plyometric exercises and drills imitating real-game scenarios.

instruction: What is the role and function of the judiciary in a democratic society? Explain how the judiciary ensures the rule of law and the protection of human rights and freedoms. Describe the structure and organization of the judiciary and how judges are appointed and removed. Give examples of the powers and responsibilities of the judiciary and how they interact with the executive and legislative branches of government.
combined_input: What is the role and function of the judiciary in a democratic society? Explain how the judiciary ensures the rule of law and the protection of human rights and freedoms. Describe the structure and organization of the judiciary and how judges are appointed and removed. Give examples of the powers and responsibilities of the judiciary and how they interact with the executive and legislative branches of government. bud judgepublicLook Cha BrianAugust
generated_output:
9, 2023

What is the role and function of the judiciary?

The judiciary is the branch of government that interprets and applies the law. It plays a crucial role in maintaining the constitutional order and the rule of law in a democratic society. The judiciary also protects the rights and freedoms of individuals and citizens from abuse and violation by the state or other actors. The judiciary ensures that the laws are consistent with the constitution, the human rights treaties and declarations, and the values and principles of the democratic system. The judiciary also resolves disputes and conflicts between different parties, such as private individuals, organizations, or other branches of government.

The judiciary is composed of courts and tribunals of various levels and jurisdictions, such as the Supreme Court, the Constitutional Court, the Court of Justice, and the Administrative Court. The highest court in the judiciary is usually the one that decides on the constitutionality of laws and acts. The lowest court is usually the one that deals with minor civil or criminal cases. The judiciary is organized into hierarchies that allow for appeals and reviews. The judges are the main decision makers in the judiciary and they are expected to be impartial, independent and competent.

How are judges appointed and removed?

Judges are appointed by the executive power, usually the head of state or the government. Depending on the system of government and the legal traditions, the appointment process may involve other actors such as the legislature, the judicial council, the legal profession or the public. The appointment process is usually based on criteria such as merit, quality and suitability. Judges may also have to go through a vetting and screening process to ensure their integrity, independence and loyalty to the law. Judges may also have to face confirmation or approval by the legislature or other bodies before they take office.

Judges remain in office until they retire, resign, are removed from office or die. Judges can only be removed from office for serious reasons, such as incompetence, misconduct, corruption, or infringement of independence. Judges may also be subject to impeachment or other procedures in exceptional circumstances, such as when they abuse their office or violate the constitution or the law. Removal proceedings are usually initiated by the executive power, the legislature or the citizens. The judiciary may review and decide on the legality of the removal proceedings.

What are the powers and responsibilities of the judiciary and how do they interact with the executive and legislative branches?

The judiciary has the power and responsibility to interpret and apply the law. This means that the judiciary has the final say on what the law means and how it should be enforced. The judiciary can also declare laws, executive acts or judicial acts as unconstitutional or invalid if they violate the constitution or the human rights standards. The judiciary can order the executive to take certain actions or refrain from certain actions if they are required by law or the court order. The judiciary can also hold the executive and the legislative accountable for their actions and decisions and ensure that they respect the rule of law and the separation of powers. The judiciary can also advise the executive and the legislative on legal issues and clarify the meaning and application of the law.

The judiciary interacts with the executive and the legislative branches through various mechanisms and channels, such as litigation, adjudication, dialogue, review and oversight. The judiciary enforces its decisions and rulings through the cooperation and compliance of the executive and the legislative branches. The judiciary respects the decisions and rulings of other authorities and judges and avoids interference or intervention in their functions and duties. The judiciary also cooperates and communicates with other branches of government and other courts and tribunals to ensure the harmonization and consistency of the law.

instruction: David is a tenant in a building owned by Emma. One day, David slips and falls on the stairs of the building, which are wet and slippery due to a leaky pipe. David suffers a broken leg and sues Emma for negligence. Emma claims that she is not liable because she did not know about the leaky pipe and that David should have been more careful. Who is likely to win the case and why? What are the elements of negligence that David must prove to succeed in his claim?
